Article.Abstract: H2-M3-restricted presentation of N-formyl methionine (f-Met) peptides to CD8(+) T cells provides a mechanism for selective recognition of bacterial infection. In this report we demonstrate that Listeria monocytogenes infection induces distinct CD8(+) T cell populations specific for each of the known Listeria-derived formyl methionine peptides presented by M3. The sum H2-M3-restricted, Listeria-specific T cell response constitutes a major fraction of the total CD8(+) T cell response to primary infection. H2-M3-restricted T cell populations expand synchronously in vivo and achieve peak frequencies approximately 2 days earlier than MHC class Ia-restricted T cell populations. Although cross-recognition of different f-Met peptides by M3-restricted T cells was previously described, costaining of CD8(+) T cells ex vivo with H2-M3 tetramers complexed with different f-Met peptides shows that the majority of Listeria-specific, M3-restricted CD8(+) T cells are peptide specific. In contrast to the highly predictable size and immunodominance hierarchies of MHC class Ia-restricted T cell responses, the magnitudes of T cell responses specific for H2-M3-restricted peptides are remarkably variable between genetically identical mice. Our findings demonstrate that H2-M3-restricted T cell responses are distinct from classically restricted T cell responses to bacterial infection.
Article.ArticleTitle: Variable immunodominance hierarchies for H2-M3-restricted N-formyl peptides following bacterial infection.
Article.Affiliations: Sections of Infectious Diseases and Immunobiology, Yale University School of Medicine, New Haven, CT 06520, USA.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with 2X10^3 Listeria for primary infection or Listeria-immune mice were reinfected with 1X10^5 L. monocytogenes to investigate recall responses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Nearly all the epitope specific CD8 T cells from mice infected with L. monocytogenes costained with M3/fMIGWII tetramers, but some fMIGWII-specific T cells from those mice did not bind the epitope/M3 tetramer. The epitope specific CD8 T cells expanded earlier than H2-Kd-restricted T cell control populations following primary L. monocytogenes infection, while little expansion of the epitope specific cells was detected after reinfection.
The epitope specific CTL cross recognized L. monocytogenes LemA peptide (fMIGWII) at high peptide concentration by CTL assay.
The epitope specific CTL cross recognized L. monocytogenes LemA peptide (fMIGWIIA) at high peptide concentration by CTL assay.
The epitope specific CTL responded to the epitope by CTL assay.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with 2X10^3 Listeria for primary infection or Listeria-immune mice were reinfected with 1X10^5 L. monocytogenes to investigate recall responses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A small portion of the epitope specific T cells costained with M3/fMIGWII (another L. monocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide) tetramer. The epitope specific CD8 T cells expanded during primary infection, peaking between days 5 and 7 postinfection, and did not expand dramatically in response to re-exposure to L. monocytogenes.
The epitope specific CTL or epitope/H2-M3 tetramer sorted cells from immune mice cross recognized L. monocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide (fMIGWII) at high peptide concentration by CTL assay.
The epitope specific CTL or epitope/H2-M3 tetramer sorted cells from immune mice responded to the epitope by CTL assay.
The epitope specific CTL recognized L. monocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide (MIVIL) at a less extent by tetramer staining.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with 2X10^3 Listeria for primary infection or Listeria-immune mice were reinfected with 1X10^5 L. monocytogenes to investigate recall responses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A small portion of the epitope specific T cells costained with M3/fMIGWII (another L. monocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide) tetramer. The epitope specific CD8 T cells expanded during primary infection, peaking between days 5 and 7 postinfection, and did not expand dramatically in response to re-exposure to L. monocytogenes.
Epitope/H2-M3 tetramer sorted cells from immune mice exhibited minimal cross recognition of other L. monocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide (fMIVTLF) by CTL assay.
The epitope specific CTL recognized L. monocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide (fMIGWIIA) at high peptide concentration by CTL assay.
The epitope specific CTL or epitope/H2-M3 tetramer sorted cells from immune mice cross-recognized L. monocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide (MIVIL) at high peptide concentration by CTL assay.

Nearly all cells that stained with M3/fMIGWIIA tetramers from L. monocytogenes infected mice costained with the epitope/M3 tetramers, but some epitope-specific T cells did not bind the M3/fMIGWIIA tetramer. These cells also expressed CD62Low.
The epitope specific CTL recognized L. monocytogenes LemA fragment 1-7 by tetramer staining.
The epitope specific CTL or epitope/H2-M3 tetramer sorted cells from immune mice responded to the epitope by CTL assay.
The epitope specific CD8 T cells expressed CD62Low.
The epitope specific CTL or epitope/H2-M3 tetramer sorted cells from immune mice exhibited minimal cross-recognition of other L. monocytocytogenes derived N-formyl peptide (MIVTLF) by CTL assay.
